item.title: Category II Garment Supply Chain Expert
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Study on Garment Ethiopia

The overall objective of the assignment is to analyse the viability of making Ethiopia a pilot country under the EU garment initiative. item.title: Security Experts, Provision of Expertise for the Election Observation Missions
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
This contract does not form part of the BENEF or COM 1 Frameworks but is Lot 1 of the EIDHR Election Framework Contract. However, the expertise required most closely aligns to BENEF Lot 7 expertise, hence we have placed these ‘calls for experts’ on the Lot 7 page of the DAI Framework Contracts website.

EIDHR Election Framework Contract

The scope of Lot 1 of the Framework Contract (FWC) is to provide expertise for the Election Observation Missions (EOMs) in order to provide support to genuine elections in partner countries. As far as the partner countries are concerned, they are in the regions of Africa, Pacific region, Asia, Latin America, North Africa and Middle East countries. The EU normally does not observe in the OSCE area but exceptions to this rule could be considered.

Election observation is a fundamental component of an election process. It is a crucial transparency check that promotes accountability and can therefore deter fraud and irregularities. This in turn can reduce violence and encourage participation. Election observation also provides wider information on a country’s human rights situation and promotes immediate and long-term democratic development.

Since 2000 the European Union (EU) has been committed to undertaking comprehensive, long-term election observation, in accordance with international standards, through the deployment of EOMs.

There is a variety of actors involved in the process:

  • EU Member States (MS) and the European Parliament (EP) are consulted on the selection of election priorities;
  • the Chief Observer is an Member of the European Parliament;
  • EU Member States identify the long and short-term observers;
  • the European Commission is responsible for the budgetary, security and logistical aspects;
  • EU Delegations on the ground are fully involved during the various steps;
  • the European External Action Service (EEAS) is in charge of the programming and political aspects.

EU EOMs are independent (from the EU Member States, the European Commission, the European Parliament) in their political judgements regarding their findings.

On average approximately 10 EU EOMs are deployed yearly to countries all over the world to the destinations mentioned in section 1.1.

EU EOMs are projects financed by the European Commission and implemented through contracting the selected Framework Contract contractor.

EU EOMs are composed of:

  • A Chief Observer (CO), Member of European Parliament designated by the High Representative/Vice-President of the European Commission (HR/VP);
  • Deputy Chief Observer (DCO) contracted by the European Commission as a Special Adviser to the HR/VP;
  • A Core Team (CT) of experts in electoral matters, selected by the European Commission and the EEAS;
  • Long and Short-term Election Observers (LTOs and STOs), volunteers proposed by the Member States (Focal Points) and selected by the European Commission and the EEAS;
  • EP Delegations;
  • Locally recruited Short-term Observers (LSTOs), EU MS diplomats posted in the partner country.

In addition to the Project Director, the tenderer is required to propose a number of experts to demonstrate the capacity to mobilise high quality experts for expert positions within Framework Contract.

The proposed experts must have an excellent proven command of *English *or *French * and a working knowledge of the other language.

Expert 4: Security Expert (Category I) and Expert 5: Security Expert (Category II)

Qualifications and skills:

  • Military or Police background and/or qualification in Security Management. Adequate training in a related field and equivalent professional experience may be accepted in lieu of a degree;
  • Previous experience in UN, EU EOM or other election observation mission;
  • Practical experience in security training of civilian international and staff recruited locally
  • First-aid experience;
  • Ability to collect, collate and assess key information from different sources prior to disseminating relevant reports and conclusions;
  • Ability to remain calm in an emergency situation;
  • High sense of responsibility, discretion and confidentiality;
  • Physically fit for duty;
  • Initiative and good judgement;
  • Courteous and tactful with ability to work effectively in a multinational and multi-cultural environment;
  • Demonstrated management skills as well as good interpersonal skills;
  • Excellent sensitive communication and training skills;
  • Demonstrated ability to support and liaise with civilian staff.

General professional experience:

  • At least 10 years of experience in the field of security including experience of minimum 5 years in international missions deploying large numbers of civilian staff (Cat.I Expert)
  • 5 years of experience for Cat.II Expert.

Specific professional experience:

  • Work experience in partner countries.
  • Participation - at co-ordination level - in the planning and implementation of election observation missions or other monitoring/peace support missions with the EU, UN or other organisations or equivalent experience in security matters targeted at civilian staff;
  • Having worked, operated or cooperated under/with UNDSS system or an equivalent security system would be an asset;
  • Experience in security training and security management of civilian international and staff recruited locally, supervision of staff recruited locally.

item.title: Project Director, Provision of Expertise for the Election Observation Missions
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
This contract does not form part of the BENEF or COM 1 Frameworks but is Lot 1 of the EIDHR Election Framework Contract. However, the expertise required most closely aligns to BENEF Lot 7 expertise, hence we have placed these ‘calls for experts’ on the Lot 7 page of the DAI Framework Contracts website.

EIDHR Election Framework Contract

The scope of Lot 1 of the Framework Contract (FWC) is to provide expertise for the Election Observation Missions (EOMs) in order to provide support to genuine elections in partner countries. As far as the partner countries are concerned, they are in the regions of Africa, Pacific region, Asia, Latin America, North Africa and Middle East countries. The EU normally does not observe in the OSCE area but exceptions to this rule could be considered.

Election observation is a fundamental component of an election process. It is a crucial transparency check that promotes accountability and can therefore deter fraud and irregularities. This in turn can reduce violence and encourage participation. Election observation also provides wider information on a country’s human rights situation and promotes immediate and long-term democratic development.

Since 2000 the European Union (EU) has been committed to undertaking comprehensive, long-term election observation, in accordance with international standards, through the deployment of EOMs.

There is a variety of actors involved in the process:

  • EU Member States (MS) and the European Parliament (EP) are consulted on the selection of election priorities;
  • the Chief Observer is an Member of the European Parliament;
  • EU Member States identify the long and short-term observers;
  • the European Commission is responsible for the budgetary, security and logistical aspects;
  • EU Delegations on the ground are fully involved during the various steps;
  • the European External Action Service (EEAS) is in charge of the programming and political aspects.

EU EOMs are independent (from the EU Member States, the European Commission, the European Parliament) in their political judgements regarding their findings.

On average approximately 10 EU EOMs are deployed yearly to countries all over the world to the destinations mentioned in section 1.1.

EU EOMs are projects financed by the European Commission and implemented through contracting the selected Framework Contract contractor.

EU EOMs are composed of:

  • A Chief Observer (CO), Member of European Parliament designated by the High Representative/Vice-President of the European Commission (HR/VP);
  • Deputy Chief Observer (DCO) contracted by the European Commission as a Special Adviser to the HR/VP;
  • A Core Team (CT) of experts in electoral matters, selected by the European Commission and the EEAS;
  • Long and Short-term Election Observers (LTOs and STOs), volunteers proposed by the Member States (Focal Points) and selected by the European Commission and the EEAS;
  • EP Delegations;
  • Locally recruited Short-term Observers (LSTOs), EU MS diplomats posted in the partner country.

Project Director

As part of the global offer, the tenderer has to identify a Project Director and one substitute, who shall at least be available and formally take over each time the Project Director is temporarily absent. It should be noted that several assignments can run in parallel. The Project Director will have an overall responsibility for the performance of the contract. In particular, the Project Director shall ensure the provision of high-quality services throughout the assignment. The Project Director will also be responsible for the day-to-day management of the contract and act as the central point of contact for each individual assignment.

The Framework Contract Project Director must have the following skills and experience:

Qualifications and skills:

  • University level education in Management, Business Administration, Public Administration, Finance, Economics, International Relations or a related field. Adequate training in a related field and equivalent professional experience in project management may be accepted in lieu of a university degree.
  • Excellent proven command (level C1of English or French, a working knowledge (level B2 of the other language).
  • Knowledge of EU institutions and policies
  • Organisational skills; planning, evaluating and problem-solving skills;
  • Demonstrated ability to work in a multi-cultural environment;
  • Financial and budget management skills;
  • Demonstrated ability to meet tight deadlines and operate under stress situations.

General professional experience

  • At least 10 years of work experience of management, implementation and administration of large-scale international operations in a multi-cultural environment in a similar position, 5 of which in a senior management position.

Specific professional experience

  • Management of large scale international operations or programmes (including with teams in the field);
  • Team management experience;
  • Experience in one or several regions where EU EOMs take place;
  • Management responsibility (contractual, financial, operational) of projects for international organisations, and in particular for EU-funded projects, would be an asset.

The Project Director will have at least the following tasks:

  • responsibility for the day-to-day management of the FWC and each individual assignment;
  • monitoring of the services rendered and of the performance of the experts implementing the individual assignments; ensuring that quality control of the Specific Contract outputs is carried out, either by the Project Director him/herself or through an identified consortium member and its staff.

item.title: AWP 2 Projects Review
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
The Beyond WTO Program (B-WTO) was developed in response to a request from the Government of Vietnam (GoV) for donor support to help with managing economic integration and the transition to a market economy following WTO accession. The B-WTO goal is “to strengthen government’s capacity to manage the integration of Vietnam into the global economy and the transition of Vietnam to a socialist market economy”. The immediate objective is “implementation of priority policy actions from the GoV’s Action Plan to enhance Vietnam’s capacity to sustain pro-poor growth (GAP)”.

The remit of this project was a review of the 2nd annual work plan’s implementation (AWP2) of Phase 2 of the B-WTO in May 2013. The objectives of the review were to:

  • Evaluate the project implementation performance and project results relative to the logical framework targets and evaluation criteria.
  • Evaluate the results achieved at the Component and Program’s level according to the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) framework of the Program.
  • Identify lessons learned from implementation, make recommendations for the remaining duration of the program and the Independent Completion Report process.
